feature_description: Intransitive verbs can form causatives in several different ways. The most frequent one is to combine a special form of the main verb with the verb hɨʔɨr (‘do’, dialect of Rutul). Another way is to combine the infinitive of the main verb with the complex verb maǯbɨr hɨʔɨr (‘force do’, dialect of Rutul). Much more rarely, the verbs ʁaʁur (‘force’), sigɨr (‘send’), χar hɨʔɨr (‘force do’), bɨjɨrmiš / bijirmiš haq'ɨri ('order do', dialect of Khnov) or wɨr (‘give’, dialect of Rutul) have been recorded as translations of our stimuli.

Another way is to combine the infinitive of the main verb with the complex verb maǯbɨr hɨʔɨr (‘force do’, dialect of Rutul). Much more rarely, the verbs ʁaʁur (‘force’), sigɨr (‘send’), χar hɨʔɨr (‘force do’), bɨjɨrmiš / bijirmiš haq'ɨri ('order do', dialect of Khnov) or wɨr (‘give’, dialect of Rutul) have been recorded as translations of our stimuli.

The most frequent one is to combine a special form of the main verb with the verb hɨʔɨr (‘do’, dialect of Rutul). Another way is to combine the infinitive of the main verb with the complex verb maǯbɨr hɨʔɨr (‘force do’, dialect of Rutul). Much more rarely, the verbs ʁaʁur (‘force’), sigɨr (‘send’), χar hɨʔɨr (‘force do’), bɨjɨrmiš / bijirmiš haq'ɨri ('order do', dialect of Khnov) or wɨr (‘give’, dialect of Rutul) have been recorded as translations of our stimuli.

feature_description: Transitive verbs can form causatives in several different ways. The most frequent one is to combine the infinitive of the main verb with the complex verb maǯbɨr hɨʔɨr (‘force do’, dialect of Rutul). The combination of the infinitive with the verb wɨr (‘give’, dialect of Rutul) is also common. Interestingly, in the dialect of Rutul contaminated constructions with the verb maǯbɨr hɨʔɨr and the verb wɨr were used several times. Much more rarely, the verbs guǯ hɨʔɨr ‘force do’, sigɨr ‘let’, bɨjɨrmiš / bijirmiš hɨʔɨr (‘order do’) or huxur (‘say’, dialect of Amsar) have been recorded as translations of our stimuli.

Interestingly, in the dialect of Rutul contaminated constructions with the verb maǯbɨr hɨʔɨr and the verb wɨr were used several times. Much more rarely, the verbs guǯ hɨʔɨr ‘force do’, sigɨr ‘let’, bɨjɨrmiš / bijirmiš hɨʔɨr (‘order do’) or huxur (‘say’, dialect of Amsar) have been recorded as translations of our stimuli.

Interestingly, in the dialect of Rutul contaminated constructions with the verb maǯbɨr hɨʔɨr and the verb wɨr were used several times. Much more rarely, the verbs guǯ hɨʔɨr ‘force do’, sigɨr ‘let’, bɨjɨrmiš / bijirmiš hɨʔɨr (‘order do’) or huxur (‘say’, dialect of Amsar) have been recorded as translations of our stimuli.
name: Nazile
answer: ajšara maǯbɨr harɨr riši ilesdɨ haʔas

Interestingly, in the dialect of Rutul contaminated constructions with the verb maǯbɨr hɨʔɨr and the verb wɨr were used several times. Much more rarely, the verbs guǯ hɨʔɨr ‘force do’, sigɨr ‘let’, bɨjɨrmiš / bijirmiš hɨʔɨr (‘order do’) or huxur (‘say’, dialect of Amsar) have been recorded as translations of our stimuli.
name: Aigul
residence_place: Последние два года живет в Тарумовке
answer: ǯižej mažbɨr harɨr ajše rɨš ʁarʁuraʔas

The most frequent one is to combine the infinitive of the main verb with the complex verb maǯbɨr hɨʔɨr (‘force do’, dialect of Rutul). The combination of the infinitive with the verb wɨr (‘give’, dialect of Rutul) is also common. Interestingly, in the dialect of Rutul contaminated constructions with the verb maǯbɨr hɨʔɨr and the verb wɨr were used several times. Much more rarely, the verbs guǯ hɨʔɨr ‘force do’, sigɨr ‘let’, bɨjɨrmiš / bijirmiš hɨʔɨr (‘order do’) or huxur (‘say’, dialect of Amsar) have been recorded as translations of our stimuli.
name: Benevshe
mothers_birthplace: мама из Кала, отец с Амсара

feature_title: Differentiation of the optative and the jussive
feature_description: The jussive (or 3rd person imperative) can be expressed by the same form as the optative (expression of blessings and curses). In other words, this feature answers the question whether the same form is used in the sentences ‘Let your parents come to school’ and ‘May Allah help you’.

feature_description: Hortative (or 1st person plural imperative) conveys an invitation to a joint action. Hortatives can be expressed by a combination of the imperative of the verb ‘go’ or a special particle (HORT.PTCL) with the infinitive of the main verb. In some dialects, when used alone, the imperative of the verb ‘go’ or the hortative particle can be used with a hortative meaning ‘let’s go!’ (cf. the map Hortative ‘Let’s go!’).
name: Abdulla

In some dialects, when used alone, the imperative of the verb ‘go’ or the hortative particle can be used with a hortative meaning ‘let’s go!’ (cf. the map Hortative ‘Let’s go!’).

Hortatives can be expressed by a combination of the imperative of the verb ‘go’ or a special particle (HORT.PTCL) with the infinitive of the main verb. In some dialects, when used alone, the imperative of the verb ‘go’ or the hortative particle can be used with a hortative meaning ‘let’s go!’ (cf. the map Hortative ‘Let’s go!’).

feature_lexeme: Gender 2 of the perfective form of the verb ‘do’
feature_description: The perfective form of the verb 'do' varies across dialects. In Gender 1 the most frequent variant is hɨʔɨ-, the other attested variants include jɨʔɨ-, and haq'ɨ-. In Gender 2 The most frequent variant is rɨʔɨ-, the other attested variants include harɨ-, harq'ɨ- and harʔɨ-. In Gender 3 the most frequent variant is wɨʔɨ-, the other attested variants include hawɨ-, habʔɨ-, habɨ- and hap'ɨ-.

In Gender 2 The most frequent variant is rɨʔɨ-, the other attested variants include harɨ-, harq'ɨ- and harʔɨ-. In Gender 3 the most frequent variant is wɨʔɨ-, the other attested variants include hawɨ-, habʔɨ-, habɨ- and hap'ɨ-.

feature_title: Universal concessive conditional clauses: presence of the additive markers
feature_description:
Universal concessive conditional clauses (such as ‘Wherever you go, I will go with you’)
can contain an additive particle. This particle is most often placed on a verb, but other positions are also possible.

Universal concessive conditional clauses (such as ‘Wherever you go, I will go with you’)
can contain an additive particle. This particle is most often placed on a verb, but other positions are also possible.
name: Nurulla
birth_place: Что бы я ему ни давала, он ничего не ест
stimuli: Что бы я ему ни давала, он ничего не ест

feature_description: Universal concessive conditional converbs are used in subordinate clauses in such sentences as ‘Wherever you go, I'll go with you’. This converb can be marked by a suffix or by a combination of a suffix and an additive particle. Note that only the use of the additive particle on the converb itself was mapped. In some cases, the additive particle can be placed in a different position in the clause; in this case, its presence is not reflected on the map.
name: Magomed
stimuli: Куда бы ты ни пошел, я с тобой пойду
answer: wɨ hile hɨxɨdde, zɨ waxʷan ruqʼusij

feature_title: Vowel fronting in human and animate plural forms
feature_description: In most dialects, certain verbs show vowel fronting when the S/P argument is human plural (as opposed to non-human plurals, including non-human animate and inanimate plural). In one dialect (that of Kina) vowel fronting is attested with non-human animate plural as well. In the verbs on the map, the root vowel -u- of the singular may alternate with -i-, -ü- or -ɨ- in the human/animate plural. In the same verbs, the stem vowel (following the root) may change from -a- or -u- to  -e-, -i-, -ɨ- or -ä-. We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire.

feature_description: In most dialects, certain verbs show vowel fronting when the S/P argument is human plural (as opposed to non-human plurals, including non-human animate and inanimate plural). In one dialect (that of Kina) vowel fronting is attested with non-human animate plural as well. In the verbs on the map, the root vowel -u- of the singular may alternate with -i-, -ü- or -ɨ- in the human/animate plural. In the same verbs, the stem vowel (following the root) may change from -a- or -u- to  -e-, -i-, -ɨ- or -ä-. We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire.

feature_description: In most dialects, certain verbs show vowel fronting when the S/P argument is human plural (as opposed to non-human plurals, including non-human animate and inanimate plural). In one dialect (that of Kina) vowel fronting is attested with non-human animate plural as well. In the verbs on the map, the root vowel -u- of the singular may alternate with -i-, -ü- or -ɨ- in the human/animate plural. In the same verbs, the stem vowel (following the root) may change from -a- or -u- to  -e-, -i-, -ɨ- or -ä-. We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire.

feature_description: In most dialects, certain verbs show vowel fronting when the S/P argument is human plural (as opposed to non-human plurals, including non-human animate and inanimate plural). In one dialect (that of Kina) vowel fronting is attested with non-human animate plural as well. In the verbs on the map, the root vowel -u- of the singular may alternate with -i-, -ü- or -ɨ- in the human/animate plural. In the same verbs, the stem vowel (following the root) may change from -a- or -u- to  -e-, -i-, -ɨ- or -ä-. We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire.

feature_description: In most dialects, certain verbs show vowel fronting when the S/P argument is human plural (as opposed to non-human plurals, including non-human animate and inanimate plural). In one dialect (that of Kina) vowel fronting is attested with non-human animate plural as well. In the verbs on the map, the root vowel -u- of the singular may alternate with -i-, -ü- or -ɨ- in the human/animate plural. In the same verbs, the stem vowel (following the root) may change from -a- or -u- to  -e-, -i-, -ɨ- or -ä-. We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire.

feature_description: In most dialects, certain verbs show vowel fronting when the S/P argument is human plural (as opposed to non-human plurals, including non-human animate and inanimate plural). In one dialect (that of Kina) vowel fronting is attested with non-human animate plural as well. In the verbs on the map, the root vowel -u- of the singular may alternate with -i-, -ü- or -ɨ- in the human/animate plural. In the same verbs, the stem vowel (following the root) may change from -a- or -u- to  -e-, -i-, -ɨ- or -ä-. We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire.

feature_description: In most dialects, certain verbs show vowel fronting when the S/P argument is human plural (as opposed to non-human plurals, including non-human animate and inanimate plural). In one dialect (that of Kina) vowel fronting is attested with non-human animate plural as well. In the verbs on the map, the root vowel -u- of the singular may alternate with -i-, -ü- or -ɨ- in the human/animate plural. In the same verbs, the stem vowel (following the root) may change from -a- or -u- to  -e-, -i-, -ɨ- or -ä-. We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire.

feature_description: In most dialects, certain verbs show vowel fronting when the S/P argument is human plural (as opposed to non-human plurals, including non-human animate and inanimate plural). In one dialect (that of Kina) vowel fronting is attested with non-human animate plural as well. In the verbs on the map, the root vowel -u- of the singular may alternate with -i-, -ü- or -ɨ- in the human/animate plural. In the same verbs, the stem vowel (following the root) may change from -a- or -u- to  -e-, -i-, -ɨ- or -ä-. We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire.

feature_description: In most dialects, certain verbs show vowel fronting when the S/P argument is human plural (as opposed to non-human plurals, including non-human animate and inanimate plural). In one dialect (that of Kina) vowel fronting is attested with non-human animate plural as well. In the verbs on the map, the root vowel -u- of the singular may alternate with -i-, -ü- or -ɨ- in the human/animate plural. In the same verbs, the stem vowel (following the root) may change from -a- or -u- to  -e-, -i-, -ɨ- or -ä-. We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire.

feature_description: In most dialects, certain verbs show vowel fronting when the S/P argument is human plural (as opposed to non-human plurals, including non-human animate and inanimate plural). In one dialect (that of Kina) vowel fronting is attested with non-human animate plural as well. In the verbs on the map, the root vowel -u- of the singular may alternate with -i-, -ü- or -ɨ- in the human/animate plural. In the same verbs, the stem vowel (following the root) may change from -a- or -u- to  -e-, -i-, -ɨ- or -ä-. We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire.

feature_description: In most dialects, certain verbs show vowel fronting when the S/P argument is human plural (as opposed to non-human plurals, including non-human animate and inanimate plural). In one dialect (that of Kina) vowel fronting is attested with non-human animate plural as well. In the verbs on the map, the root vowel -u- of the singular may alternate with -i-, -ü- or -ɨ- in the human/animate plural. In the same verbs, the stem vowel (following the root) may change from -a- or -u- to  -e-, -i-, -ɨ- or -ä-. We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire.

feature_description: In most dialects, certain verbs show vowel fronting when the S/P argument is human plural (as opposed to non-human plurals, including non-human animate and inanimate plural). In one dialect (that of Kina) vowel fronting is attested with non-human animate plural as well. In the verbs on the map, the root vowel -u- of the singular may alternate with -i-, -ü- or -ɨ- in the human/animate plural. In the same verbs, the stem vowel (following the root) may change from -a- or -u- to  -e-, -i-, -ɨ- or -ä-. We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire.

feature_description: In most dialects, certain verbs show vowel fronting when the S/P argument is human plural (as opposed to non-human plurals, including non-human animate and inanimate plural). In one dialect (that of Kina) vowel fronting is attested with non-human animate plural as well. In the verbs on the map, the root vowel -u- of the singular may alternate with -i-, -ü- or -ɨ- in the human/animate plural. In the same verbs, the stem vowel (following the root) may change from -a- or -u- to  -e-, -i-, -ɨ- or -ä-. We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire.

feature_description: In most dialects, certain verbs show vowel fronting when the S/P argument is human plural (as opposed to non-human plurals, including non-human animate and inanimate plural). In one dialect (that of Kina) vowel fronting is attested with non-human animate plural as well. In the verbs on the map, the root vowel -u- of the singular may alternate with -i-, -ü- or -ɨ- in the human/animate plural. In the same verbs, the stem vowel (following the root) may change from -a- or -u- to  -e-, -i-, -ɨ- or -ä-. We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire.

feature_description: In most dialects, certain verbs show vowel fronting when the S/P argument is human plural (as opposed to non-human plurals, including non-human animate and inanimate plural). In one dialect (that of Kina) vowel fronting is attested with non-human animate plural as well. In the verbs on the map, the root vowel -u- of the singular may alternate with -i-, -ü- or -ɨ- in the human/animate plural. In the same verbs, the stem vowel (following the root) may change from -a- or -u- to  -e-, -i-, -ɨ- or -ä-. We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire.

feature_description: In most dialects, certain verbs show vowel fronting when the S/P argument is human plural (as opposed to non-human plurals, including non-human animate and inanimate plural). In one dialect (that of Kina) vowel fronting is attested with non-human animate plural as well. In the verbs on the map, the root vowel -u- of the singular may alternate with -i-, -ü- or -ɨ- in the human/animate plural. In the same verbs, the stem vowel (following the root) may change from -a- or -u- to  -e-, -i-, -ɨ- or -ä-. We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire.

We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire.

In the same verbs, the stem vowel (following the root) may change from -a- or -u- to  -e-, -i-, -ɨ- or -ä-. We use hulqas ‘play’ (dialect of Rutul), ʁurʁas ‘stroll’ (dialect of Rutul), and suq’as ‘sit’ (dialect of Rutul), as diagnostic verbs. Verbs with the root vowel -a- may also be involved in the alternation (a~e); these verbs were not included in the questionnaire.
